questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presented with dysphagia. Identify the diagnosis from upper GI biopsy of esophagus showed in the following picture?

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins
Interference with bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit
Inhibition of bacterial DNA replication by targeting DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Disruption of bacterial cell membrane integrity, leading to leakage of intracellular components

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is being treated for complicated intra-abdominal infection involving Bacteroides fragilis and Escherichia coli. He is currently on a broad-spectrum antibiotic regimen. If a fluoroquinolone is part of his regimen, which of the following is its primary mechanism of action against E. coli?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Inhibition of bacterial DNA replication by targeting DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV

questions.text: Organism showing “Medusa head” appearance and “Bamboo stick” appearance in blood culture medium. What is the likely organisms?

choices.text: Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver induced due to OCPs
Nutmeg liver with pale areas of necrosis and dark congested areas of perivenular viable hepatocytes

questions.text: A liver biopsy reveals following findings. What is true about this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, a lifelong heavy smoker, presents with progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral, predominantly basilar, subpleural reticular opacities with honeycombing. A lung biopsy shows extensive interstitial fibrosis and characteristic "fibroblast foci". Immunohistochemistry for a specific mucin is performed to differentiate this condition from other fibrosing lung diseases. Which mucin expression pattern would be most characteristic of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF)?

A patient with bipolar disorder taking carbamazepine for mood stabilization develops a maculopapular rash and mild elevation of liver enzymes after a new antiepileptic drug is added for seizure control. Which of the following co-administered antiepileptic drugs is most likely responsible for precipitating these adverse effects, especially through inhibition of its metabolism?

choices.text: Positive blood culture from the CVC lumen with Staphylococcus epidermidis
Peripheral blood culture turning positive 2 hours before the CVC blood culture
CVC blood culture turning positive ≥ 2 hours before the peripheral blood culture
Gram stain of the CVC lumen culture showing a high concentration of organisms

questions.text: A central venous catheter (CVC) inserted for total parenteral nutrition in a critically ill patient is suspected to be the source of a bloodstream infection. Blood cultures from the CVC lumen and a peripheral vein are drawn simultaneously. Which finding would definitively confirm the CVC as the source of infection, distinguishing it from a contaminant or another source?
questions.solution: Ans. C) CVC blood culture turning positive ≥ 2 hours before the peripheral blood culture

choices.text: It is highly virulent and often forms true hyphae
It is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole
It produces a capsule that evades phagocytosis
It rapidly disseminates through the lymphatic system

questions.text: A patient undergoing chemotherapy for acute leukemia develops neutropenic fever. Initial broad-spectrum antibiotics are started. Subsequently, blood cultures grow Candida glabrata. Which of the following characteristics of C. glabrata makes it a challenging nosocomial pathogen in this scenario?
questions.solution: Ans. B) It is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole

questions.text: Which of the following classes of antibiotics should be avoided in patients with a history of Myasthenia Gravis due to the potential to exacerbate muscle weakness?

choices.text: Efflux pumps actively transporting the drug out of the cell

questions.text: A patient with a severe Gram-negative infection is being treated with gentamicin. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for bacterial resistance to aminoglycosides like gentamicin?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Enzymatic modification of the drug

questions.text: A patient with benign hypertrophy of prostate was admitted in the hospital for 3 weeks. He subsequently developed suspected catheter associated-urinary tract infection. The tip of the catheter was sent for culture and was grown on blood agar. After 24 hours, the blood agar shows the following appearance. What is the most likely causative agent for the UTI?

A 58-year-old man suffered road traffic accident and came to the hospital. He had multiple fractures in his lower limbs, ribs and lung contusion. Ultimately he succumbed to his injuries. At autopsy, a biopsy from the lung showed the following appearance. What is the most likely cause of his death?
Cat scratch disease is caused by:

choices.text: Overexpression of AmpC beta-lactamase, which is inducible
Production of plasmid-mediated enzymes that hydrolyze most penicillins, cephalosporins, and aztreonam
Chromosomal mutations leading to target site alteration
Intrinsic resistance to all beta-lactams due to lack of a peptidoglycan layer

questions.text: A patient develops a surgical site infection (SSI) after a colon resection. Culture of the wound swab grows Escherichia coli and Bacteroides fragilis. The E. coli isolate is extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) positive. Which resistance mechanism is characteristic of ESBL-producing E. coli?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Production of plasmid-mediated enzymes that hydrolyze most penicillins, cephalosporins, and aztreonam

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with chronic dyspepsia and unexplained weight loss. Upper GI endoscopy reveals a large, ulcerated lesion in the lesser curvature of the stomach. Biopsy shows signet ring cells infiltrating the gastric wall without forming definite glandular structures. Immunohistochemistry is likely to reveal:

A patient with epilepsy is prescribed phenytoin. Which of the following adverse effects is dose-independent and often requires genetic testing (HLA-B*1502 allele screening) in certain populations before initiation of therapy?
Maximum risk of carcinoma pancreas is seen in which of these?

A 35-year-old female with a history of oral contraceptive use presents with acute right upper quadrant pain. Imaging reveals a solitary, well-demarcated hepatic mass. Surgical resection is performed. Histological examination shows sheets of hepatocytes with normal-appearing nuclei, prominent arterial vessels, and absence of normal bile ducts. Scattered areas of sinusoidal dilatation and peliosis hepatis are noted. This lesion is most likely a:

A 70-year-old male is prescribed a benzodiazepine for insomnia. He also has a history of mild cognitive impairment and occasional falls. Which of the following benzodiazepines would be the most appropriate choice to minimize the risk of prolonged sedation and increased fall risk in this elderly patient?
A 30-year-old male is having productive cough with dysnea. Blood gas analysis shows low PaO2. Chest x-ray is showing reticulonodular pattern. The causative agent is:

A 68-year-old heavy smoker presents with confusion and seizures. Lab results show a serum sodium of 115 mEq/L, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine. A chest CT scan reveals a large central hilar mass. A biopsy from this mass shows sheets of small, round cells with scant cytoplasm, "salt-and-pepper" chromatin, and extensive basophilic staining of blood vessel walls. What is the cause of this basophilic staining?

A surgical patient develops a urinary tract infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa resistant to multiple antibiotics, including piperacillin-tazobactam and ceftazidime. Susceptibility testing reveals sensitivity only to amikacin and colistin. The resistance pattern strongly suggests the presence of which type of beta-lactamase in Pseudomonas?
Patient presents with watery diarrhea after 24 hours of sea food ingestion. Probable organism is:

Which of the following antipsychotic drugs has the highest propensity for causing significant weight gain and metabolic syndrome (hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia), making it a challenging choice for patients with pre-existing metabolic risks?

A 45-year-old female presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). Anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are detected in high titers. A liver biopsy shows florid duct lesions, lymphocytic inflammation, and progressive destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Which of the following pathological findings, if present, would indicate a poorer prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis

questions.text: A patient with a penicillin allergy, specifically delayed maculopapular rash, develops a severe Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. Which of the following beta-lactam antibiotics can be safely used with a low risk of cross-reactivity in this patient?

A 60-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and steatorrhea. Imaging reveals pancreatic calcifications. Biopsy of the pancreas is performed, showing widespread destruction of acinar cells, fibrosis, and chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Despite medical management, his symptoms persist. Which of the following genetic mutations is most commonly associated with hereditary pancreatitis and would predispose this patient to his condition?

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus; Alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs)
Pseudomonas aeruginosa; Efflux pumps and outer membrane porin loss

questions.text: A 68-year-old male, intubated and mechanically ventilated for acute respiratory distress syndrome, develops a new onset fever, purulent tracheal aspirate, and worsening oxygenation on day 7 of hospitalization. Gram stain of the aspirate shows Gram-negative rods. Given his prolonged ventilation, which of the following is the most likely causative organism, and what is its characteristic resistance mechanism to carbapenems?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Klebsiella pneumoniae; Carbapenemase production

choices.text: It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T-lymphocytes.
It is directly correlated with high peak serum vancomycin concentrations.
It is due to histamine release from mast cells, often preventable by slowing infusion rate.
It indicates cross-reactivity with beta-lactam antibiotics.

questions.text: A patient receiving prolonged intravenous vancomycin develops "Red Man Syndrome." Which of the following statements regarding this adverse effect is true?
questions.solution: Ans. C) It is due to histamine release from mast cells, often preventable by slowing infusion rate.

choices.text: Acute dopamine receptor blockade in the nigrostriatal pathway
Serotonin 2A receptor antagonism in the mesocortical pathway
Long-term dopamine receptor supersensitivity in the nigrostriatal pathway
Cholinergic receptor blockade in the basal ganglia

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with schizophrenia, on long-term treatment with a conventional antipsychotic, presents with involuntary, repetitive, purposeless movements of his mouth, tongue, and grimacing. These movements worsen when his medication dose is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this adverse effect?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Long-term dopamine receptor supersensitivity in the nigrostriatal pathway
